computer.description:
These photos were sent by Pablo Alvarez Doval (Thank you!). This computer belongs to his uncle, unfortunately, he has no information about it. He says: "It's a huge computer, built in a metallic desk, with a printer, two 8" floppy drives, 12" green-screen monitor (I am not sure, but I do believe it is 12"), and a keyboard, everything you needed built in. It even had a chair to compliment it! Obviously, it is some kind of office computer".
It has indeed a 12" screen (white characters 25 x 80) en two 8" floppy drives 1,2 MB. A harddisk was optional. The programming language was Phocal. (Philips Office Computer Assembly Language).
The printer was a 9 pins dot matrix, 100 cps. The P330 was the last product of the Philips Office computers series. Then Philips came with the mircro computers and later the IBM compatibele PC's.
In 1992 the Philips computer line was ended.
_______
Contributors : Pablo Alvarez Doval, Roy Van Der Lee

item.description: ROM card #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;ROM CARD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Two ROM cards are connected together, side by side.<
RAM card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;RAM CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>32 KB RAM card (16x4116 chips). Provision is made for a second 32 KB RAM bank. <
CPU card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;CPU CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the NEC 8080 processor at the upper right corner. I/O chips come also from NEC and Intel. <
FDD card #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;FDD CARD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Like the ROM cards, two FDD cards are connected together.<
FDD card #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;FDD CARD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The second FDD card uses its own 8080 microprocessor, also a NEC version.<

computer.media: 2 x 8'' FDD, optional 7 MB 8'' hard diskPrograms loading was done by a minicassete software called PIOC (Program Input Output Cassette)
computer.name: P/330

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;PHILIPS P/430 KEYBOARD AND CONTROL PANEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>We are looking information about this machine.<br> Holger Groh is also looking for any technical information and documentation in order to bring his P/430 back to life.<
<br><font color="red"><strong>&gt;&nbsp;16-INCH HDD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Same capacity as a basic usb key but 10,000 times more heavy!<
